TypeSignature.Value: public class UINavigationBar : MonoTouch.UIKit.UIView, IDisposable, MonoTouch.UIKit.IUIBarPositioning

.class public auto ansi beforefieldinit UINavigationBar extends MonoTouch.UIKit.UIView implements class MonoTouch.Foundation.INSCoding, class MonoTouch.ObjCRuntime.INativeObject, class MonoTouch.UIKit.IUIBarPositioning, class System.IDisposable

Docs.summary: A that displays the standard hierarchical navigation metaphor for iOS.

remarks.para: The MonoTouch API supports two styles of event notification: the Objective-C style that uses a delegate class or the C# style using event notifications.

The C# style allows the user to add or remove event handlers at runtime by assigning to the events of properties of this class. Event handlers can be anyone of a method, an anonymous methods or a lambda expression. Using the C# style events or properties will override any manual settings to the Objective-C Delegate or WeakDelegate settings.

The Objective-C style requires the user to create a new class derived from class and assign it to the property. Alternatively, for low-level control, by creating a class derived from which has every entry point properly decorated with an [Export] attribute. The instance of this object can then be assigned to the property.
The maintains a stack of s. The displays the . You can push and pop s using and .
The is most commonly seen in conjunction with a , which manages the and pushes and pops the necessary s.

Each defines left, center, and right subviews. The left and right subviews are expected to be of type , while the center subview by default displays the value of the property. The center view can be further customized by assigning to the property.
When used with a , the current 's property is used to manipulate the , as shown in the following example.
Application developers who wish to customize the behavior of the 's uniquely-styled '"Back" button when using a can use the following technique:

Docs.related: Add a Nav Bar Bottom ToolBar
Add a Nav Bar Right Button

MemberSignature.Value: public UINavigationBar (MonoTouch.Foundation.NSCoder coder);
.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSCoder coder) cil managed

Docs.param: The unarchiver object.
Docs.summary: A constructor that initializes the object from the data stored in the unarchiver object.

remarks.para: This constructor is provided to allow the class to be initialized from an unarchiver (for example, during NIB deserialization). This is part of the protocol.

If developers want to create a subclass of this object and continue to support deserialization from an archive, they should implement a constructor with an identical signature: taking a single parameter of type and decorate it with the [Export("initWithCoder:"] attribute declaration.
The state of this object can also be serialized by using the companion method, EncodeTo.

MemberSignature.Value: public UINavigationBar (MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t);
.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t) cil managed
protected UINavigationBar (MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t);
.method familyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t) cil managed

Docs.param: Unused sentinel value, pass NSObjectFlag.Empty.
Docs.summary: Constructor to call on derived classes to skip initialization and merely allocate the object.

remarks.para: This constructor should be called by derived classes when they completely construct the object in managed code and merely want the runtime to allocate and initialize the NSObject. This is required to implement the two-step initialization process that Objective-C uses, the first step is to perform the object allocation, the second step is to initialize the object. When developers invoke the constructor that takes the NSObjectFlag.Empty they take advantage of a direct path that goes all the way up to NSObject to merely allocate the object's memory and bind the Objective-C and C# objects together. The actual initialization of the object is up to the developer.

This constructor is typically used by the binding generator to allocate the object, but prevent the actual initialization to take place. Once the allocation has taken place, the constructor has to initialize the object. With constructors generated by the binding generator this means that it manually invokes one of the "init" methods to initialize the object.
It is the developer's responsibility to completely initialize the object if they chain up using the NSObjectFlag.Empty path.

In general, if the developer's constructor invokes the NSObjectFlag.Empty base implementation, then it should be calling an Objective-C init method. If this is not the case, developers should instead chain to the proper constructor in their class.

The argument value is ignored and merely ensures that the only code that is executed is the construction phase is the basic NSObject allocation and runtime type registration. Typically the chaining would look like this:

Docs.param: Pointer (handle) to the unmanaged object.
Docs.summary: A constructor used when creating managed representations of unmanaged objects; Called by the runtime.

remarks.para: This constructor is invoked by the runtime infrastructure () to create a new managed representation for a pointer to an unmanaged Objective-C object. Developers should not invoke this method directly, instead they should call the GetNSObject method as it will prevent two instances of a managed object to point to the same native object.

Docs.param: Frame used by the view, expressed in iOS points.
Docs.summary: Initializes the UINavigationBar with the specified frame.

remarks.para: This constructor is used to programmatically create a new instance of UINavigationBar with the specified dimension in the frame. The object will only be displayed once it has been added to a view hierarchy by calling AddSubview in a containing view.
This constructor is not invoked when deserializing objects from storyboards or XIB filesinstead the constructor that takes an NSCoder parameter is invoked.

MemberSignature.Value: public static MonoTouch.UIKit.UINavigationBar.UINavigationBarAppearance Appearance { get; }
.property class MonoTouch.UIKit.UINavigationBar/UINavigationBarAppearance Appearance

Docs.summary: Strongly-typed property that returns the UIAppearance class for this class.

remarks.para: Setting any appearance properties on this instance will affect the appearance of all instances of UINavigationBar.
If developers want to control the appearance of subclasses of UINavigationBar, they should use the method.

MemberSignature.Value: public static MonoTouch.UIKit.UINavigationBar.UINavigationBarAppearance AppearanceWhenContainedIn (Type[] containers);
.method public static hidebysig class MonoTouch.UIKit.UINavigationBar/UINavigationBarAppearance AppearanceWhenContainedIn(class System.Type[] containers) cil managed

Docs.param: List of types that developers want to have as the containers to apply this particular appearance
Docs.summary: Returns a strongly typed UIAppearance for instances of this class when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy.
Docs.returns: The appearance proxy object that developers can use to set properties when the given container hierarchy is active

remarks.para: The returned object represents the UIAppearance proxy where developers can set appearance properties for instances of UINavigationBar when those instances are contained in the hierarchy specified by the parameter.
If developers want to control the appearance of subclasses of UINavigationBar, they should use the method.
The following example shows how the AppearanceWhenContainedIn method works

example.code: var mySliders = UISlider.AppearanceWhenContainedIn (typeof (UINavigationBar), typeof (UIPopoverController)); mySliders.TintColor = UIColor.Red;

remarks.para: For more information, see the documentation for the class.

Docs.summary: The handle for this class.
Docs.value: The pointer to the Objective-C class.
Docs.remarks: Each MonoTouch class mirrors an unmanaged Objective-C class. This value contains the pointer to the Objective-C class, it is similar to calling objc_getClass with the object name.

.property instance class MonoTouch.UIKit.IUINavigationBarDelegate Delegate

Docs.summary: An instance of the MonoTouch.UIKit.UINavigationBarDelegate model class which acts as the class delegate.

value.para: The instance of the MonoTouch.UIKit.UINavigationBarDelegate model class

remarks.para: The delegate instance assigned to this object will be used to handle events or provide data on demand to this class.
When setting the Delegate or WeakDelegate values events will be delivered to the specified instance instead of being delivered to the C#-style events

This is the strongly typed version of the object, developers should use the WeakDelegate property instead if they want to merely assign a class derived from NSObject that has been decorated with [Export] attributes.

MemberSignature.Value: protected override void Dispose (bool disposing);
.method familyhidebysig virtual instance void Dispose(bool disposing) cil managed

param.name: disposing
param.para: If set to , the method is invoked directly and will dispose manage and unmanaged resources; If set to the method is being called by the garbage collector finalizer and should only release unmanaged resources.

Docs.summary: Releases the resources used by the UINavigationBar object.

remarks.para: This Dispose method releases the resources used by the UINavigationBar class.

This method is called by both the Dispose() method and the object finalizer (Finalize). When invoked by the Dispose method, the parameter disposing is set to and any managed object references that this object holds are also disposed or released; when invoked by the object finalizer, on the finalizer thread the value is set to .

Calling the Dispose method when the application is finished using the UINavigationBar ensures that all external resources used by this managed object are released as soon as possible. Once developers have invoked the Dispose method, the object is no longer useful and developers should no longer make any calls to it.

For more information on how to override this method and on the Dispose/IDisposable pattern, read the ``Implementing a Dispose Method'' document at http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/fs2xkftw.aspx

Docs.param: The encoder object where the state of the object will be stored
Docs.summary: Encodes the state of the object on the provided encoder

remarks.para: This method is part of the protocol and is used by applications to preserve the state of the object into an archive.
Users will typically create a and then invoke the which will call into this method

If developers want to allow their object to be archived, they should override this method and store their state in using the provided parameter. In addition, developers should also implement a constructor that takes an NSCoder argument and is exported with [Export ("initWithCoder:")]

Docs.typeparam: The type for which the UIAppearance proxy must be returned. This is a subclass of UINavigationBar.

summary.para: Obtains the appearance proxy for the subclass of UINavigationBar.

returns.para: appearance proxy object for the specified type.

remarks.para: Setting any appearance properties on the returned object will affect the appearance of all classes and subclasses of the type parameter.
Unlike the property, or the method which only work on instances of this particular class, the proxies returned by GetAppearance can be used to change the style of subclasses.
The following example shows how the GetAppearance method works
For more information, see the documentation for the class.

List of types that the developer wishes to have as the containers to apply this particular appearance.

summary.para: Obtains the appearance proxy for the subclass of UINavigationBar that has the specified trait collection when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy.

returns.para: appearance proxy object for the specified type.

remarks.para: The returned object represents the UIAppearance proxy where developers can set appearance properties for instances of UINavigationBar that has the specified trait collection when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy when those instances are contained in the hierarchy specified by the parameter.
Unlike the property, or the method which only work on instances of this particular class, the proxies returned by GetAppearance can be used to change the style of subclasses.
The following example shows how the GetAppearance method works

example.code: var myTheme = UINavigationBar.GetAppearance<MyUINavigationBarSubclass> (myTraits, typeof (UINavigationBar), typeof (UIPopoverController)); myTheme.TintColor = UIColor.Red;

remarks.para: For more information, see the documentation for the class.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObject WeakDelegate { get; set; }
.property instance class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObject WeakDelegate

Docs.summary: An object that can respond to the delegate protocol for this type

value.para: The instance that will respond to events and data requests.

remarks.para: The delegate instance assigned to this object will be used to handle events or provide data on demand to this class.
When setting the Delegate or WeakDelegate values events will be delivered to the specified instance instead of being delivered to the C#-style events

Methods must be decorated with the [Export ("selectorName")] attribute to respond to each method from the protocol. Alternatively use the Delegate method which is strongly typed and does not require the [Export] attributes on methods.
